text.content: Donning or removing armor follows the times listed for the armor. Other worn items, such as cloaks or rings, usually take an action to put on or take off unless the GM rules otherwise.
Drawing or stowing a weapon is normally part of the attack you make on your turn. Switching a held item between hands or retrieving it from a backpack may require an action at the GM's discretion.
Some magic items are designed to function as a pair. Benefits usually apply only while both items are worn or wielded together, and they may share attunement requirements.

A magic item that requires a command word can be activated by speaking that word while touching or wielding the item. Saying the word takes no more effort than speaking normally, but the item allows only one use per applicable activation.
Consumable magic items, such as potions and scrolls, are expended after one use. Drinking a potion usually takes an action. If a consumable fails, it has no effect but is still spent.

Magic items with charges expend them when you activate their powers. Unless stated otherwise, an item regains expended charges at dawn, and if the last charge is spent the item might become nonmagical.

Magic items that allow you to cast spells specify the action required, the spell level, and any costs such as expending charges. Unless an item states otherwise, you use your own spellcasting ability when making spell attacks or setting save DCs.
